prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The main aim of this project is to detect continuum emission associated with dusty envelopes/disk in young sub-stellar objects. We will observe in dual polarization mode using three basebands of 1.875 GHz bandwidth each with a channel spacing of ~2.5 km/s after spectral averaging, centered strategically at certain frequencies to get serendipitous detections of C18O(3-2), SiO(5-4), and DCN(3-2) and to have the best atmospheric transmission. We plan to add all channels without emission to produce the continuum image.
As a completly secondary goal and without decreasing significantly the continuum sensitivity for performing the proposed continuum studies, we will place one of the spectral windows in baseband 1 in the transition CO(2-1) with a bandwidth of 468.75 MHz and a resolution of 488 KHz in order to get serendipitous detections of possible gas emission associated to an envelope/disk/jet system. This will allow us to detect gas with a velocity resolution of 0.6 km/s (enough to sample typical velocities of several km/s associated to these fenomena) and at a sensitivity of 8 mJy/beam. We plan to smooth channels in order to get higher sinal-to-noise ratio if weak emission is present.

The expected size of the objects of interest is ~6" and we aim to trace spatial scales of ~110 AU, which is 0.8" at a distance of 140 pc. We selected the C36-2 configuration in band 6 to get the spatial resolution of 0.8". We will not filter any extended emission therefore we do not need to use the ACA.

The primary goal of this proposal is to detect dust emission surrounding young sub-stellar objects, therefore the sensitivity requirements are based on the continuum flux. We require an rms of 0.07 mJy in order to detect the expected continuum emission (>0.5 mJy) with a signal-to-noise ratio greater than 7.
As a completely secondary goal and without decreasing appreciably the total observing time, we placed one of the spectral windows in baseband 1 in the transition CO(2-1) in order to get serendipitous detections of possible gas emission associated to an envelope/disk/jet system. This will allow us to detect gas with a velocity resolution of 0.6 km/s (enough to sample typical velocities of several km/s associated to these fenomena) and at a sensitivity of 8 mJy/beam. We plan to smooth channels in order to get higher sinal-to-noise ratio if weak emission is present.

As a completely secondary goal and without decreasing appreciably the total observing time, we placed one of the spectral windows in baseband 1 in the transition CO(2-1) in order to get serendipitous detections of possible gas emission associated to an envelope/disk/jet system. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Lupus 1 and 3 southern molecular clouds are excellent laboratories to study the formation processes of sub-stellar objects. Our group (SOLA consortium) has identified a set of pre- and proto-stellar candidates of substellar nature using 1.1mm ASTE/AzTEC maps and analyzing its SED using our optical to submillimeter database. We propose continuum observations at 1.3mm using 0.8" spatial resolution towards the most promising pre- and proto-brown dwarfs candidates found in Lupus 1 and 3. Our aims are to characterize the dust envelope/disk surrounding these sub-stellar objects, as well as measure the disk mass in the more evolved ones (Class II equivalent). ALMA observations of this sample have a potential to, for the first time, provide a general picture of how substellar objects form and evolve, from the equivalent to the pre-stellar cores to the Class II stage in the low mass regime of star formation. Our sample comprises 33 pre-stellar objects, 7 Class 0 and I objects, and 22 Class II objects. This proposal, requesting only 6.8hr time, will provide an important insight on the formation of brown dwarfs.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
